title: Multivariate ordinal response
text: Let \(Y = (y_1,\ldots, y_K)\) \(K\)-vector ordinal responses, without loss generality denote \(y_k =0,1,\ldots, m_k -1\) may rating scores provided different readers subject’s medical image. vector-valued response can partially ordered component-wise consensus, , say \(Y_i\prec Y_j\) \(Y_i\leq Y_j\) component-wise, strict inequality least one component. Alternatively, reader, say first one, experienced rest, score can prioritized. say \(Y_i\prec Y_j\) \(y_{1i} < y_{1j}\), \(y_{1i} = y_{1j}\) consensus order holds components. either case, assume higher score better, \(Y_i\succ Y_j\) (\(Y_j\prec Y_i\)) means “win” \(Y_i\) “loss” \(Y_j\).

title: Multivariate ordinal response
text: Let \(Z = 1, 0\) binary indicator treatment control groups, respectively. probability treated winning untreated \(P(Y_i\succ Y_j\mid Z_i = 1, Z_j = 0)\). Likewise, treated losing untreated \(P(Y_i\prec Y_j\mid Z_i = 1, Z_j = 0)\). summarize relative favorability treatment control: \[\begin{align}\tag{1} \mbox{Win ratio: } \hspace{1ex}&  WR = \frac{P(Y_i\succ Y_j\mid Z_i = 1, Z_j = 0)}{P(Y_i\prec Y_j\mid Z_i = 1, Z_j = 0)}\\ \mbox{Net benefit: } \hspace{1ex}&  NB = P(Y_i\succ Y_j\mid Z_i = 1, Z_j = 0) - P(Y_i\prec Y_j\mid Z_i = 1, Z_j = 0). \end{align}\] Given \((Y_i, Z_i)\) \((=1,\ldots, n)\), random \(n\)-sample \((Y, Z)\), standard two-sample \(U\)-statistics can used estimate win loss probabilities, can replace target quantities (1) nonparametric estimates WR NB.

title: Multivariate ordinal response
text: \(Z\) non-binary rather \(p\)-vector possibly continuous components, nonparametric approach longer works. Instead, posit multiplicative win ratio model \[\begin{align}\tag{2} WR(Z_i, Z_j) := \frac{P(Y_i\succ Y_j\mid Z_i, Z_j)}{P(Y_i\prec Y_j\mid Z_i, Z_j)} =\exp\{\beta^{\rm T}(Z_i - Z_j)\}. \end{align}\] means unit increases covariates lead win ratios \(\exp(\beta)\) (component-wise). Standard estimators \(\exp(\beta)\) reduce two-sample win ratio \(Z = 1, 0\).

title: Multivariate ordinal response
text: Load package:

title: Multivariate ordinal response
text: two-sample WR/NB, Y1 Y0 response matrices treatment control, respectively, \(K\) columns \(K\) components. fun can user-defined function takes two \(K\)-vectors outputs \(1\), \(-1\), \(0\) first wins, loses, ties second, respectively. default function consensus (product) order. win ratio regression, Y \(n\times K\) response matrix \(Z\) \(n\times p\) design (covariate) matrix. , win function can customized fun. summary(obj) print summary results including regression tables.
code: wrtest(Y1, Y0, fun = wprod) obj <- wreg(Y, Z, fun = wprod)

title: Multivariate ordinal response
text: total 186 patients non-alcoholic fatty liver disease recruited University Wisconsin Hospitals 2017. patients underwent computed tomography scan liver presence non-alcoholic steato-hepatitis, severe form non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. image subsequently assessed two radiologists using scale 1 5, higher values indicating greater likelihood disease. Predictors rating scores include patient sex, presence advanced fibrosis (AF), quantitative biomarkers percent steatosis, .e., liver fat content, liver mean gray level intensity, liver surface nodularity (LSN) score. First, compare bivariate scores AF non-AF win ratio/net benefit: shows, particular, AF \(1-0.56=44\%\) less likely non-AF favorable scores consensus two readers. regress scores covariates, basic information model printed, like number percentage comparable pairs used regression, well regression coefficients (log-WR). detailed inference results: Advanced fibrosis status percent steatosis strongly significantly associated likelihood non-alcoholic steato-hepatitis. particular, AF \(38.1\%\) times likely favorable reader assessments non-AF. Furthermore, one percentage point increase steatosis results \(1-97259\doteq 2.7\%\) reduction likelihood favorable assessments.
code: head(liver) #>   R1NASH R2NASH Sex    AF Steatosis  SSF2  LSN #> 1      3      2   M FALSE        30  0.21 2.33 #> 2      1      1   F FALSE         5  0.38 2.86 #> 3      4      2   M FALSE        70  0.58 3.65 #> 4      4      4   F  TRUE        30 -0.08 2.73 #> 5      4      3   M  TRUE        70 -0.04 2.53 #> 6      3      3   M FALSE        10  0.02 2.88 # lower score is better Y1 <- 5 - liver[liver$AF, c("R1NASH", "R2NASH")] # advanced Y0 <- 5 - liver[!liver$AF, c("R1NASH", "R2NASH")] # not advanced obj <- wrtest(Y1, Y0) obj #> Call: #> wrtest(Y1 = Y1, Y0 = Y0) #>  #> Two-sample (Y1 vs Y0) win ratio/net benefit analysis #>  #> Number of pairs: N1 x N0 =  69 x 116  =  8004  #>   Win: 2392 (29.9%) #>   Loss: 4251 (53.1%) #>   Tie: 1361 (17%) #>  #> Win ratio (95% CI): 0.56 (0.37, 0.86), p-value = 0.00856547 #> Net benefit (95% CI): -0.232 (-0.4, -0.065), p-value = 0.006577537 Y <- 5 - liver[, c("R1NASH", "R2NASH")] # lower score is better Z <- cbind("Female" = liver$Sex == "F",            liver[, c("AF", "Steatosis",   "SSF2",  "LSN")]) # covariates obj <- wreg(Y, Z) # fit model obj #> Call: #> wreg(Y = Y, Z = Z) #>  #> n = 154 subjects with complete data #> Comparable (win/loss) pairs: 9548/11781 = 81% #>  #>    Female         AF   Steatosis         SSF2        LSN #>  -0.18956 -0.9660827 -0.02779146 -0.007926333 -0.1029914 summary(obj) #> Call: #> wreg(Y = Y, Z = Z) #>  #> n = 154 subjects with complete data #> Comparable (win/loss) pairs: 9548/11781 = 81% #>  #> Newton-Raphson algoritm converged in 7 iterations #>  #>                coef exp(coef)  se(coef)      z Pr(>|z|)     #> Female    -0.189560    0.8273  0.259988 -0.729 0.465934     #> AF        -0.966083    0.3806  0.280313 -3.446 0.000568 *** #> Steatosis -0.027791    0.9726  0.005281 -5.262 1.42e-07 *** #> SSF2      -0.007926    0.9921  0.003953 -2.005 0.044953 *   #> LSN       -0.102991    0.9021  0.125718 -0.819 0.412657     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #>           exp(coef) exp(-coef) lower .95 upper .95 #> Female      0.82732    1.20872   0.49702    1.3771 #> AF          0.38057    2.62763   0.21970    0.6592 #> Steatosis   0.97259    1.02818   0.96258    0.9827 #> SSF2        0.99210    1.00796   0.98445    0.9998 #> LSN         0.90213    1.10848   0.70512    1.1542 #>  #> Overall Wald test = 79.129 on 5 df,  p = 1.221245e-15

title: Multivariate ordinal response
text: Confirm wreg() AF covariate Z produces results wrtest. Try different win function, e.g., one prioritizes score reader 1, `fun` compare results consensus order.

code: @Manual{,   title = {poset: Analysis of Partially Ordered Data},   author = {Lu Mao},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 1.0.0, https://lmaowisc.github.io/poset/},   url = {https://sites.google.com/view/lmaowisc/}, }

title: Analysis of Partially Ordered Data
text: poset package implements simple efficient statistical procedures partially ordered data, like multivariate ordinal response consensus prioritized order. current version focuses win ratio/net benefit approach (Mao 2024).

title: Analysis of Partially Ordered Data
text: Install poset CRAN : can install development version GitHub :

title: Analysis of Partially Ordered Data
text: basic example two-sample testing regressio .
code: library(poset) ## data example head(liver) #>   R1NASH R2NASH Sex    AF Steatosis  SSF2  LSN #> 1      3      2   M FALSE        30  0.21 2.33 #> 2      1      1   F FALSE         5  0.38 2.86 #> 3      4      2   M FALSE        70  0.58 3.65 #> 4      4      4   F  TRUE        30 -0.08 2.73 #> 5      4      3   M  TRUE        70 -0.04 2.53 #> 6      3      3   M FALSE        10  0.02 2.88

what: Compare bivariate ratings by fibrosis stage
title: Analysis of Partially Ordered Data
code: Y1 <- liver[liver$AF, c("R1NASH", "R2NASH")] # advanced Y0 <- liver[!liver$AF, c("R1NASH", "R2NASH")] # not advanced wrtest(Y1, Y0) #> Call: #> wrtest(Y1 = Y1, Y0 = Y0) #>  #> Two-sample (Y1 vs Y0) win ratio/net benefit analysis #>  #> Number of pairs: N1 x N0 =  69 x 116  =  8004  #>   Win: 4251 (53.1%) #>   Loss: 2392 (29.9%) #>   Tie: 1361 (17%) #>  #> Win ratio (95% CI): 1.78 (1.16, 2.73), p-value = 0.00856547 #> Net benefit (95% CI): 0.232 (0.065, 0.4), p-value = 0.006577537

title: Analysis of Partially Ordered Data

what: Two-sample win ratio (net benefit) analysis — wrtest
title: Two-sample win ratio (net benefit) analysis — wrtest
text: Estimate make inference win ratio (net benefit) comparing treatment control group.

title: Two-sample win ratio (net benefit) analysis — wrtest
Two-sample win ratio (net benefit) analysis — wrtest
text: Y1 \(K\)-variate response data \(n_1\) subjects treatment (\(n_1\times K\) matrix). Y0 \(K\)-variate response data \(n_0\) subjects control (\(n_0\times K\) matrix). fun User-specified win function pairwise comparison. takes two arguments \(y_1\) \(y_0\) (\(p\)-dimensional) returns 1 \(y_1\) wins, -1 \(y_0\) wins, 0 tied. default wprod based product order multivariate ordinal data.

title: Two-sample win ratio (net benefit) analysis — wrtest
text: object class wrtest following components: theta bivariate vector win/loss fractions LWR. lgwr, lgwr_se, lgwr_pval Log-win ratio estimate, standard error, p-value. nb, nb_se, nb_pval Net benefit estimate (theta[1]-theta[2]), standard error, p-value.

title: Two-sample win ratio (net benefit) analysis — wrtest
text: Mao, L. (2024). Win ratio partially ordered data. Statistica Sinica, revision. Buyse, M. (2010).  Generalized pairwise  comparisons prioritized outcomes two-sample problem.  Statistics Medicine, 29, 3245-3257.

title: Two-sample win ratio (net benefit) analysis — wrtest
code: head(liver) #>   R1NASH R2NASH Sex    AF Steatosis  SSF2  LSN #> 1      3      2   M FALSE        30  0.21 2.33 #> 2      1      1   F FALSE         5  0.38 2.86 #> 3      4      2   M FALSE        70  0.58 3.65 #> 4      4      4   F  TRUE        30 -0.08 2.73 #> 5      4      3   M  TRUE        70 -0.04 2.53 #> 6      3      3   M FALSE        10  0.02 2.88 ## compare bivariate ratings by fibrosis stage ## lower score is better Y1 <- liver[liver$AF, c("R1NASH", "R2NASH")] # advanced Y0 <- liver[!liver$AF, c("R1NASH", "R2NASH")] # not advanced obj <- wrtest(Y1, Y0) obj #> Call: #> wrtest(Y1 = Y1, Y0 = Y0) #>  #> Two-sample (Y1 vs Y0) win ratio/net benefit analysis #>  #> Number of pairs: N1 x N0 =  69 x 116  =  8004  #>   Win: 4251 (53.1%) #>   Loss: 2392 (29.9%) #>   Tie: 1361 (17%) #>  #> Win ratio (95% CI): 1.78 (1.16, 2.73), p-value = 0.00856547 #> Net benefit (95% CI): 0.232 (0.065, 0.4), p-value = 0.006577537 #>

what: The product-order win function for multivariate ordinal data — wprod
title: The product-order win function for multivariate ordinal data — wprod
text: commonly used rule compare    multivariate ordinal data wrtest. winner components    greater equal loser, strictly    least one component.

title: The product-order win function for multivariate ordinal data — wprod
The product-order win function for multivariate ordinal data — wprod
text: y1 \(K\)-dimensional vector \(y_1\). y2 \(K\)-dimensional vector  \(y_2\).

title: The product-order win function for multivariate ordinal data — wprod
text: integer \({1, 0, -1}\): 1 \(y_1 \ge y_2\) component-wise, strict inequality least                  one component. -1 \(y_0 \ge y_2\) component-wise, strict inequality least                  one component. 0 Otherwise.

title: Win ratio regression analysis — wreg
text: Fit multiplicative win-ratio regression model partially ordered outcome covariates.

title: Win ratio regression analysis — wreg
code: wreg(Y, Z, fun = NULL, sfun = NULL, ep = 1e-06)

title: Win ratio regression analysis — wreg
text: Y \(n\times K\) matrix \(K\)-variate response data \(n\) subjects.  entries must numeric scores.  pseudo-efficient estimation specifying score function sfun,  average score across components (row means) compatible partial order (.e., monotone function ordered elements). Z \(n\times p\) design matrix covariates. fun User-specified win function pairwise comparison. takes two arguments \(y_1\) \(y_0\) (\(p\)-dimensional) returns 1 \(y_1\) wins, -1 \(y_0\) wins, 0 tied. default wprod based product order multivariate ordinal data. sfun score function used pseudo-efficient estimation. default mean component-wise numeric scores Y. ep Convergence criterion Newton-Raphson algorithm. default 1e-6.

title: Win ratio regression analysis — wreg
text: object class wreg following components: beta vector estimated regression coefficients. var Estimated covariance matrix beta l Number Newton-Raphson iterations. beta_nv Naive (non-pseudo-efficient) estimates beta. se_nv Estimated standard errors beta_nv. n Sample size \(n\) input data non-missing values. Nwl Number comparable pairs (win loss) \(n(n-1)/2\) possible ones.

title: Win ratio regression analysis — wreg
text: Mao, L. (2024). Win ratio partially ordered data. Statistica Sinica, revision.

title: Win ratio regression analysis — wreg
code: head(liver) #>   R1NASH R2NASH Sex    AF Steatosis  SSF2  LSN #> 1      3      2   M FALSE        30  0.21 2.33 #> 2      1      1   F FALSE         5  0.38 2.86 #> 3      4      2   M FALSE        70  0.58 3.65 #> 4      4      4   F  TRUE        30 -0.08 2.73 #> 5      4      3   M  TRUE        70 -0.04 2.53 #> 6      3      3   M FALSE        10  0.02 2.88 # regress bivariate ratings against covariates Y <- 5 - liver[, c("R1NASH", "R2NASH")] # lower score is better Z <- cbind("Female" = liver$Sex == "F",            liver[, c("AF", "Steatosis",   "SSF2",  "LSN")]) # covariates obj <- wreg(Y, Z) # fit model obj #> Call: #> wreg(Y = Y, Z = Z) #>  #> n = 154 subjects with complete data #> Comparable (win/loss) pairs: 9548/11781 = 81% #>  #>    Female         AF   Steatosis         SSF2        LSN #>  -0.18956 -0.9660827 -0.02779146 -0.007926333 -0.1029914 summary(obj) #> Call: #> wreg(Y = Y, Z = Z) #>  #> n = 154 subjects with complete data #> Comparable (win/loss) pairs: 9548/11781 = 81% #>  #> Newton-Raphson algoritm converged in 7 iterations #>  #>                coef exp(coef)  se(coef)      z Pr(>|z|)     #> Female    -0.189560    0.8273  0.259988 -0.729 0.465934     #> AF        -0.966083    0.3806  0.280313 -3.446 0.000568 *** #> Steatosis -0.027791    0.9726  0.005281 -5.262 1.42e-07 *** #> SSF2      -0.007926    0.9921  0.003953 -2.005 0.044953 *   #> LSN       -0.102991    0.9021  0.125718 -0.819 0.412657     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #>           exp(coef) exp(-coef) lower .95 upper .95 #> Female      0.82732    1.20872   0.49702    1.3771 #> AF          0.38057    2.62763   0.21970    0.6592 #> Steatosis   0.97259    1.02818   0.96258    0.9827 #> SSF2        0.99210    1.00796   0.98445    0.9998 #> LSN         0.90213    1.10848   0.70512    1.1542 #>  #> Overall Wald test = 79.129 on 5 df,  p = 1.221245e-15
